5.text:
Thank you. (Applause.) Thank you so much,
everybody. Everybody, have a seat. Thank you,

17.text:
Doctor, for that introduction. I want to thank
Sylvia Burwell, our outstanding head of Health

27.text:
and Human Services. We’ve got some wonderful
members of Congress here today who helped

33.text:
make this happen. And I want to offer a heartfelt
thanks to all of the top medical professionals

40.text:
who are here today. We’ve got hospital leaders,
we’ve got health care CEOs, doctors, patients,

47.text:
advocates, consumer groups, Democrats and
Republicans, who have all come together and

53.text:
spent time and effort to make the Affordable
Care Act, and America’s health care system,

62.text:
What your efforts have meant is the start
of a new phase, where professionals like you

67.text:
and organizations like yours come together
in one new network with one big goal, and

71.text:
that is to continue to improve the cost and
quality of health care in America.

78.text:
A lot of you have already taken steps on your
own. The American Cancer Society that’s

84.text:
represented here is committed to teaching
its members about how new patient-centered

89.text:
approaches can improve cancer care. Governor
Markell of Delaware, who’s here, has set

95.text:
a goal of having 80 percent of his citizens
receive care through new and improved payment

101.text:
and delivery models within five years. And
Dr. Glenn Madrid, of Grand Junction, Colorado,

109.text:
is using a new care model that allowed him
to hire case coordinators and use better technology

113.text:
so that patients have access to him 24/7.
I don’t know when that lets him sleep -- but

123.text:
And these are examples of efforts that show
we don’t need to reinvent the wheel; you’re

129.text:
already figuring out what works to reduce
infections in hospitals or help patients with

133.text:
complicated needs. What we have to do is to
share these best practices, these good ideas,

139.text:
including new ways to pay for care so that
we’re rewarding quality. And that’s what

145.text:
In fact, just five years in, the Affordable
Care Act has already helped improve the quality

151.text:
of health care across the board. A lot of
the attention has been rightly focused on

157.text:
people’s access to care, and that obviously
was a huge motivator for us passing the Affordable

164.text:
Care Act -- making sure that people who didn’t
have health insurance have the security of

171.text:
But what was also a central notion in the
Affordable Care Act was we had an inefficient

176.text:
system with a lot of waste that didn’t also
deliver the kind of quality that was needed

185.text:
that often put health care providers in a
box where they wanted to do better for their

190.text:
patients, but financial incentives were skewed
the other way.

195.text:
And so the work that we’ve been able to
do is already spurring the kinds of changes

200.text:
that we had hoped for. It’s helped reduce
hospital readmission rates dramatically. It’s

207.text:
a major reason why we’ve seen 50,000 fewer
preventable patient deaths in hospitals. And

214.text:
if you want to know what that means, ask Alicia
Cole, who suffers -- Alicia is right here

220.text:
-- who suffers the long-term effects of a
hospital-acquired infection. And she is here

225.text:
today because she doesn’t want anybody else
to endure what she has. And it's preventable

232.text:
if we set up good practices, and financial
incentives, reimbursement incentives, are

241.text:
So making sure that the Affordable Care Act
works as intended, to not only deliver access

249.text:
to care but also to improve the quality of
care and the cost of care, that’s something

255.text:
that requires all of us to work together.
That’s part of what the law is all about.

259.text:
It’s making health coverage more affordable
and more effective for all of us. And in a

266.text:
lot of ways, it’s working better than many
of us, including me, anticipated. (Laughter.)

275.text:
Wherever you are, here’s why you should
care about making this system more efficient,

280.text:
and here’s why you should care that we keep
the Affordable Care Act in place.

288.text:
If you get insurance through your employer,
like most Americans do, the ACA gave you new

293.text:
savings and new protections. If you’ve got
a pre-existing condition like diabetes or

297.text:
cancer, if you’ve had heartburn or a heart
attack, this law means that you can no longer

303.text:
be charged more or denied coverage because
of a preexisting condition, ever. It’s the

309.text:
end of the discrimination against the sick
in America, and all of us are sick sometimes.

315.text:
If you don’t have health insurance, you
can go online to the marketplace and choose

320.text:
from an array of quality, affordable private
plans. Every governor was given the option

325.text:
to expand Medicaid for his or her citizens,
although only 28 have chosen to do so -- so

331.text:
far. But after five years of the ACA, more
than 16 million uninsured Americans have gained

337.text:
health care coverage -- 16 million. In just
over one year, the ranks of the uninsured

343.text: have dropped by nearly one-third -- one-third.

349.text:
If you’re a woman, you can no longer be
charged more just for being a woman. And you

354.text:
know there are a lot of women. (Laughter.)
Like more than 50 percent. (Laughter.) Preventive

361.text:
care, like routine checkups and immunizations
and contraception now come with no additional

367.text:
If you’re a young person, you can now stay
on your parents’ plan until you turn 26.

373.text:
And if you want to turn that new idea into
a business, if you’re going to try different

378.text:
jobs, even a different career, you now have
the freedom to do it because you can buy health

382.text:
care that’s portable and not tied to your
employer. Most people have options that cost

389.text:
If you’re a business owner -- because when
we put forward the Affordable Care Act, there

396.text:
was a lot of question about how it would affect
business; well, it turns out employer premiums

399.text:
rose at a rate tied for the lowest on record.
If premiums had kept growing at the rate we

407.text:
saw in the last decade, then either the average
family premium, paid by the family or paid

414.text:
by the business, would be $1,800 higher than
it is today. That’s 1,800 bucks that businesses

422.text:
can use to higher and invest, or that’s
1,800 bucks that stays in that family’s

428.text: bank account, shows up in their paycheck.

434.text:
If you’re a senior -- more than 9 million
seniors and people with disabilities have

438.text:
saved an average of $1,600 on their prescriptions,
adding up to over $15 billion in savings.

448.text:
There were fears promoted that somehow this
was going to undermine Medicare. Well, it

452.text:
turns out the life of the Medicare Trust Fund
has been extended by 13 years since this law

459.text:
And, relevant to the topic today, we’re
moving Medicare toward a payment model that

465.text:
rewards quality of care instead of quantity
of care. We don’t want the incentives to

472.text:
be skewed so that providers feel obliged to
do more tests; we want them to do the right

479.text:
tests. We want them, perhaps, to save -- to
invest some money on the front end to prevent

487.text:
disease and not just on the back end to treat
disease. And so these changes are encouraging

493.text:
doctors and hospitals to focus on getting
better outcomes for their patients.

499.text:
As we speak, Congress is working to fix the
Medicare physician payment system. I’ve

503.text:
got my pen ready to sign a good, bipartisan
bill -- (applause) -- which would be really

512.text:
exciting. I love when Congress passes bipartisan
bills that I can sign. (Laughter.) It’s

520.text:
always very encouraging. And I want to thank
everybody here today for their work in supporting

526.text: new models of care that will benefit all Americans.

529.text:
But the bottom line is this for the American
people: The Affordable Care Act, this law,

534.text:
is saving money for families and for businesses.
This law is also saving lives -- lives that

546.text:
touch all of us. It’s working despite countless
attempts to repeal, undermine, defund, and

555.text:
It’s not the “job-killer” that critics
have warned about for five years. When this

561.text:
law was passed, our businesses began the longest
streak of private-sector job growth on record:

567.text:
60 straight months, five straight years, 12
million new jobs.

571.text:
It’s not the fiscal disaster critics warned
about for five years. Health care prices are

577.text:
rising at the slowest rate in nearly 50 years,
which has helped cut our deficit by two-thirds

582.text:
since I took office. Before the ACA, health
care was the single biggest driver driving

588.text:
up our projected deficits. Today, health care
is the single biggest factor driving those

595.text:
I mean, we have been promised a lot of things
these past five years that didn’t turn out

601.text:
to be the case: death panels, doom. (Laughter.)
A serious alternative from Republicans in

618.text:
The budget they introduced last week would
literally double the number of the uninsured

621.text:
in America. And in their defense, there are
two reasons why coming up with their own alternative

631.text:
First, it’s because the Affordable Care
Act pretty much was their plan before I adopted

637.text:
it -- (laughter) -- based on conservative,
market-based principles developed by the Heritage

643.text:
Foundation and supported by Republicans in
Congress, and deployed by a guy named Mitt

648.text:
Romney in Massachusetts to great effect. If
they want to take credit for this law, they

655.text: can. I’m happy to share it. (Laughter.)

658.text:
And second, it’s because health reform is
really hard and the people here who are in

663.text:
the trenches know that. Good people from both
parties have tried and failed to get it done

669.text:
for 100 years, because every public policy
has some trade-offs, especially when it affects

675.text:
one-sixth of the American economy and applies
to the very personal needs of every individual

681.text:
And we’ve made our share of mistakes since
we passed this law. But we also know beyond

688.text:
a shred of a doubt that the policy has worked.
Coverage is up. Cost growth is at a historic

695.text:
low. Deficits have been slashed. Lives have
been saved. So if anybody wants to join us

703.text:
in the spirit of the people who have put aside
differences to come here today and help make

708.text: the law work even better, come on board.

713.text:
On the other hand, for folks who are basing
their entire political agenda on repealing

718.text:
the law, you’ve got to explain how kicking
millions of families off their insurance is

723.text:
somehow going to make us more free. Or why
forcing millions of families to pay thousands

729.text:
of dollars more will somehow make us more
secure. Or why we should go back to the days

735.text:
when women paid more for coverage than men.
Or a preexisting condition locked so many

746.text:
And if that's your argument, then you should
meet somebody like Anne Ha, who is here. Anne

752.text:
is 28 years old. Where’s Anne? There you
are. Anne runs her own business in Philadelphia.

760.text:
And she thought what many of us think when
we're young -- I no longer qualify -- (laughter)

770.text:
-- that she was too young, too healthy to
bother with health insurance. She went to

775.text:
the gym every day. She ate healthy, looks
great, felt invincible. Why pay a doctor just

784.text:
But then her mom called, as moms sometimes
do, and told Anne to get insured against the

791.text:
“what ifs” of life. What if you get sick?
What if you get into a car accident? So Anne,

798.text:
dutiful daughter that she was, went to HealthCare.gov,
checked out her options in the marketplace.

804.text:
And thanks to the tax credits available to
her under this law, she got covered for 85

807.text:
bucks a month. Four months later, Anne was
diagnosed with early-stage stomach cancer.

818.text:
Anne underwent surgery, endured chemo. Today,
she’s recovering. She looks great. She’s

823.text:
here with us at the White House. She invited
me to her wedding. I told her you don't want

833.text:
“If I didn’t have insurance,” Anne wrote,
“my stomach cancer would have gone undiscovered,

840.text:
slowly and silently killing me. But because
I did have insurance, I was given a chance

845.text: to live a long and happy life.” (Applause.)

859.text:
And so in September, Anne is going to be marrying
her fiancé, Tom. And she’s convinced him

863.text:
to get covered, too. And I do appreciate,
Michelle appreciates the invitation. As I

869.text:
said, we have to mag people at the wedding,
and it spoils the fun. (Laughter.)

876.text:
But here are two lessons from Anne’s story.
Number one: Listen to your mom. (Laughter.)

885.text:
Number two: The Affordable Care Act works.
And it’s working not just to make sure that

893.text:
folks like Anne get coverage, but it’s also
working to make sure that the system as a

901.text:
whole is providing better quality at a better
price, freeing up our providers to do the

914.text:
things that led them to get into health care
in the first place -- and that's help people.

925.text:
Five years ago, we declared that in the United
States of America, the security of quality,

929.text:
affordable health care was a privilege -- was
not a privilege, but a right. And today, we’ve

935.text:
got citizens all across the country, all of
you here today who are helping make that right

943.text:
a reality for every American, regardless of
your political beliefs, or theirs. And we're

950.text:
saving money in the process. And we're cutting
the deficit in the process. And we're helping

956.text:
businesses in their bottom lines in the process.
We're making this country more competitive

963.text:
And it’s not going to happen overnight.
There are still all kinds of bumps along the

969.text:
way. Health care is complicated stuff. And
the hospital executives who are here, and

977.text:
the doctors who are here, and the consumer
advocates who are here can tell you -- all

983.text:
the complications and the quirks not just
to the Affordable Care Act, but just generally

988.text:
making the system more rational and more efficient,
it takes some time. But we're on our way.

995.text:
And if all of us summon the same focus, the
same kind of courage and wisdom and hard work

1004.text:
that so many of you in this room display;
and if we keep working not against one another,

1011.text:
but for one another, with one another, we
will not just make progress in health care.

1015.text:
We're going to keep on making sure that across
the board we're living up to our highest ideals.

1020.text:
So I very much am appreciative of what all
of you are doing. I’m very proud of you.

1027.text:
And why don't you guys get back to work? (Laughter.)
Thank you very much. (Applause.)
